questions.question: (2 times repeated) - One of the following is a cause of dyspnea of sudden onset:
questions.explanation: Pulmonary Embolism (PE) typically presents with the abrupt onset of dyspnea due to sudden occlusion of pulmonary arteries. Chronic heart failure, fibrosis, obesity, and anemia cause gradual or progressive dyspnea.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - The hallmark of aplastic anemia is:
questions.explanation: Pancytopenia (reduction in RBCs, WBCs, and platelets) is the hallmark of aplastic anemia due to bone marrow failure. While individual cell lines are low, the defining feature is the depression of all three.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: (4 times repeated) - One of the strong and independent risk factors for hypertension is:
questions.explanation: Obesity is a major, independent risk factor for essential hypertension, contributing to increased sympathetic activity and insulin resistance. High potassium, low sodium, and exercise are protective/lifestyle modifications.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Imaging of the chest in sarcoidosis may reveal:
options: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal involvement
questions.explanation: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (BHL) is the classic radiographic finding in Stage I sarcoidosis. Parenchymal involvement appears in Stage II. The other options are not characteristic primary findings of sarcoidosis.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Orthopnea may occur in:
questions.explanation: Orthopnea (dyspnea when lying flat) is a specific sign of Left Sided Heart Failure due to the redistribution of blood from the splanchnic circulation and lower extremities to the lungs, increasing pulmonary congestion.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Which of the following physical signs may indicate left ventricular failure:
questions.explanation: Pulsus alternans (alternating strong and weak beats) is a specific sign of severe left ventricular failure, reflecting impaired myocardial contractility. Congested neck veins are a sign of Right HF.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Thrombocytopenia is not present in the following:
questions.explanation: Iron deficiency anemia typically presents with normal or elevated platelet counts (reactive thrombocytosis). Thrombocytopenia is characteristic of marrow failure, hypersplenism, and consumption/destruction disorders.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Which of the following does not produce continuous murmur:
questions.explanation: Peripheral pulmonary stenosis produces a systolic murmur, not a continuous one. Continuous murmurs occur when there is a pressure gradient between two chambers/vessels throughout both systole and diastole (e.g., PDA, AV fistula).
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Decapitated hypertension means:
options: Drop in blood pressure as a consequence of heart failure
Drop in blood pressure as a consequence of thyrotoxicosis
Drop in blood pressure as a consequence of hypovolemia
Drop in blood pressure as a consequence of excess therapy
Drop in blood pressure as a consequence of salt wasting
questions.explanation: Decapitated hypertension refers to a situation where a previously hypertensive patient develops normal or low blood pressure due to pump failure (Heart Failure), indicating a poor prognosis.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - One of the following signs may indicate acute severe asthma:
questions.explanation: Pulsus paradoxus (a drop in SBP >10 mmHg during inspiration) is a sign of severe asthma and impending respiratory failure due to extreme intrathoracic pressure swings. Breath sounds are usually decreased (silent chest) in severe cases.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Pathological consequences of hypertension involve the following organs:
options: Heart, brain, kidneys and peripheral arteries
questions.explanation: Hypertension causes target organ damage primarily in the Heart (LVH, HF), Brain (Stroke), Kidneys (Nephrosclerosis), and Arteries (Atherosclerosis, Retinopathy).
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Abdominal pain in a case of irritable bowel syndrome:
questions.explanation: A hallmark diagnostic criterion for IBS (Rome criteria) is abdominal pain that is relieved by defecation. It is often exacerbated by food intake, not decreased.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Hodgkin disease is characterized mainly by:
questions.explanation: The presence of Reed-Sternberg cells (binucleated giant cells) in the lymph node biopsy is the pathological hallmark required for the diagnosis of Hodgkin Lymphoma.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: The following statement is not true as regard GERD:
options: More common in males than females
Barrett esophagus is more common in males
questions.explanation: GERD is frequently associated with extra-esophageal symptoms such as chronic cough, laryngitis, asthma, and dental erosion. The statement that it is 'never' associated is false.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Aetiology of liver cirrhosis not include:
questions.explanation: Acute Viral Hepatitis A is a self-limiting infection and does not cause chronic liver disease or cirrhosis. Cirrhosis results from chronic insults like Hep B/C, alcohol, or metabolic diseases.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Accelerated atherosclerosis occurs in:
questions.explanation: Diabetes Mellitus is a major risk factor for atherosclerosis due to hyperglycemia, dyslipidemia, and endothelial dysfunction, leading to accelerated vascular disease.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Pregnancy-associated hypertension should not be treated with: (check 9216 for more)
questions.explanation: Telmisartan (and other ARBs/ACE inhibitors) are contraindicated in pregnancy due to the risk of fetal renal defects and oligohydramnios. Methyldopa and Labetalol are first-line safe options.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following drugs used in HF through increases heart contractility by acting on myosin and decreasing its sliding?
questions.explanation: Digitalis (Digoxin) is a positive inotrope that increases contractility by inhibiting the Na+/K+ ATPase, leading to increased intracellular calcium.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: One of the following is not a common finding in sarcoidosis:
questions.explanation: While Sarcoidosis can cause hypercalcemia which might affect kidneys, frank renal failure is not a 'common' presentation compared to lymphadenopathy, constitutional symptoms, or hepatosplenomegaly. Parotid enlargement occurs in Heerfordt's syndrome.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Palpable adventitious sounds over the chest wall which disappear after cough may be:
questions.explanation: Rhonchi (palpable as fremitus) caused by secretions in the large airways often clear or change character after coughing. Obstructions by tumors or nodes are fixed and do not clear.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Hemoptysis:
options: Vasculitides are the most common aetiology
Fungal infection is not a cause
questions.explanation: Hemoptysis is a potentially serious symptom that can indicate malignancy, TB, or PE. It must always be investigated to rule out life-threatening causes.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - One of the following is a sign of vasovagal attack:
questions.explanation: A vasovagal attack (neurocardiogenic syncope) is characterized by paradoxical bradycardia and hypotension (vasodilation) due to increased vagal tone.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following is not used in treatment of digitalis toxicity:
questions.explanation: Hemoperfusion is ineffective for Digoxin toxicity because the drug has a very large volume of distribution and is tissue-bound. IV Calcium is traditionally avoided/used with caution, but Hemoperfusion is strictly not used.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - A 28-year-old pregnant female presented by placental abruption. Initial investigations revealed prolonged PT and PTT, thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen concentration. The most appropriate diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: The clinical picture of placental abruption with coagulopathy (prolonged PT/PTT, low fibrinogen, low platelets) is classic for Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC), a consumptive coagulopathy.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: Bovine (non-explosive) cough may indicate:
questions.explanation: A bovine cough lacks the explosive character of a normal cough due to the inability to close the vocal cords (glottis), which is caused by Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve palsy.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Differentiation between asthma and COPD may include:
questions.explanation: Asthma is characterized by reversible airway obstruction. Significant reversibility (FEV1 increase >12-15% or >200ml) after bronchodilator administration distinguishes it from COPD, which is largely irreversible.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Anti-hypertensive drug contraindicated in renal artery stenosis:
questions.explanation: Losartan (ARB) and ACE inhibitors are contraindicated in bilateral renal artery stenosis (or stenosis in a solitary kidney) because they efferently dilate the glomerulus, dropping GFR and precipitating acute renal failure.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - The typical symptoms of GERD (Gastro-esophageal reflux) include: (check 9215 for more explanation)
questions.explanation: Regurgitation and heartburn are the two cardinal/typical symptoms of GERD. Cough, chest pain, and wheezing are atypical/extra-esophageal presentations.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Chest pain caused by diseases of respiratory system usually originates from involvement of:
questions.explanation: The lung parenchyma and visceral pleura are insensitive to pain. Respiratory chest pain (pleurisy) arises from irritation of the parietal pleura, which is richly innervated.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Digital clubbing is not a common finding in:
questions.explanation: Digital clubbing is typically NOT a feature of COPD alone. If present in a COPD patient, it usually implies a co-existing cause like lung cancer or bronchiectasis.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered as a compensatory mechanism for HF?
questions.explanation: Elevated BP (increased afterload) is detrimental to a failing heart. The compensatory mechanisms attempt to maintain cardiac output via rate (SNS), volume (RAS), contractility/mass (Hypertrophy), and efficiency (O2 extraction).
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: treatment of megaloblastic anemia:
options: Folic acid should be given before Vit B12
Vit B12 should be given before folic acid
Oral iron should be given at first
questions.explanation: Vitamin B12 must be administered before or with Folic Acid. Treating B12 deficiency with Folate alone corrects the anemia but allows neurological damage (Subacute Combined Degeneration) to progress.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: alarm features in a case of irritable bowel syndrome include:
options: Family history of irritable bowel syndrome
questions.explanation: Unexplained weight loss is a 'Red Flag' or alarm feature that excludes simple IBS and necessitates investigation for malignancy, IBD, or malabsorption. Other red flags include rectal bleeding and nocturnal symptoms.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - One of the following is true about renin:
options: Converts angiotensin I to angiotensin II
The net effect is to lower blood pressure
questions.explanation: Renin is an enzyme released by the juxtaglomerular cells of the kidney in response to hypovolemia (low renal perfusion). It converts Angiotensinogen to Angiotensin I.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: In diagnosis of restrictive cardiomyopathy, which of the following has most relevance?
questions.explanation: Bi-atrial enlargement is a hallmark of restrictive cardiomyopathy due to high filling pressures and diastolic dysfunction, often while ventricular size remains normal.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Hemoptysis does not occur in:
questions.explanation: Pulmonary stenosis decreases pulmonary blood flow and does not cause pulmonary congestion or hemorrhage. LVF, Mitral Stenosis, Bronchiectasis, and Goodpasture's all cause bleeding/congestion.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - As regard palpitation, which of the following is not true:
options: Coronary artery disease has a higher risk
Life-threatening recurrent ventricular arrhythmias require implantable cardioverter device
May be accompanied by other symptoms like lightheadedness
Holter ECG may be required for evaluation
questions.explanation: Arrhythmias do NOT always cause palpitations; many are asymptomatic. Palpitations are the subjective awareness of the heartbeat.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is associated with:
questions.explanation: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is strongly associated with autoimmune phenomena, particularly Warm Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia (AIHA) and ITP.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: Which of the following tests assesses functional states of the liver?
questions.explanation: The INR (Prothrombin Time) measures the liver's synthetic function (production of clotting factors). Enzymes like ALT/GGT indicate injury, not function.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - One of the clinical manifestations of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is:
questions.explanation: Altered bowel habits (constipation, diarrhea, or mixed) are the core manifestation of IBS. Fever, anemia, and blood are red flags against the diagnosis.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Cardiac involvement is uncommon in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation: While severe hypocalcemia can affect the heart, Vitamin D deficiency itself is not a primary cause of specific cardiomyopathy compared to Duchenne's, Friedreich's, or Myotonic dystrophy which have well-defined cardiac associations.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with splenomegaly?
questions.explanation: Hereditary Spherocytosis causes extravascular hemolysis in the spleen, leading to splenomegaly. Sickle cell causes auto-splenectomy (shrinkage) in adults.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: Drug of choice in Mycoplasma pneumonia is:
questions.explanation: Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall, making beta-lactams (Penicillin/Cephalosporins) ineffective. Macrolides (Erythromycin) are the drug of choice.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: In acute pneumonia, the following is required except:
questions.explanation: Pulmonary Function Tests (PFTs) are not indicated in acute pneumonia and can be difficult to perform. They are used for chronic conditions like COPD/Asthma.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Which of the following is not a common cause for malabsorption syndrome?
questions.explanation: Staphylococcal food poisoning is an acute, self-limiting toxin-mediated illness causing vomiting/diarrhea, not a chronic malabsorption syndrome.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: (3 times repeated) - Which of the following is the surest sign of upper motor neurone (pyramidal) lesion?
questions.explanation: Organic clonus (sustained rhythmic contractions) is a definitive sign of Upper Motor Neuron (Pyramidal) lesions. Fasciculations are LMN signs.
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: (3 times repeated) - Female patient without known previous past history presented by marked elevation of liver enzymes, prolonged PT, and encephalopathy. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: Fulminant Hepatic Failure (Acute Liver Failure) is defined by the rapid onset of encephalopathy and coagulopathy (Prolonged PT) in a patient without prior liver disease.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: A patient presented by hemiplegia of sudden onset. The most probable aetiology is:
questions.explanation: Sudden onset (seconds to minutes) suggests an Embolic event. Thrombosis is usually more gradual (hours/sleep), and neoplasm/degeneration are slow.
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: One of the following is a common skin finding in sarcoidosis:
questions.explanation: Erythema Nodosum (painful red nodules on shins) is a classic cutaneous manifestation of acute Sarcoidosis (part of Lofgren's syndrome).
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with encephalopathy. He was found to have a blood pressure of 240/150. Which of the following drugs can be used?
questions.explanation: In hypertensive emergencies, potent/rapid agents are needed. Furosemide is effective particularly if there is associated fluid overload/HF. Note: Modern guidelines prefer IV Labetalol or Nitroprusside, but Furosemide is the best option among the list provided compared to oral agents like Atenolol.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - One of the following conditions will not cause secondary hypertension:
questions.explanation: Addison's disease (Adrenal insufficiency) typically causes Hypotension due to cortisol and aldosterone deficiency (salt wasting). All others are established causes of secondary hypertension.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) will not be prolonged in which of the following conditions:
questions.explanation: Thrombocytopenia (low platelets) affects primary hemostasis (Bleeding time) but does not prolong coagulation tests like aPTT or PT, which measure clotting factors.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - The most specific diagnostic test for sarcoidosis is:
questions.explanation: Trans-bronchial biopsy demonstrating non-caseating granulomas is the Gold Standard for definitive diagnosis. ACE and Calcium are supportive but non-specific.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: The primary determinant of extracellular fluid volume is:
questions.explanation: Sodium is the main cation of the extracellular fluid (ECF) and, due to its osmotic effect, is the primary determinant of ECF volume.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following is not true regarding Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM):
options: Condition improves on passive leg raising
questions.explanation: Beta-agonists (like adrenaline/dopamine) increase contractility, which worsens the dynamic outflow obstruction in HOCM. Beta-blockers are the treatment of choice.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Restrictive lung disease will cause mainly:
questions.explanation: Restrictive lung diseases reduce total lung volume (FVC decreases), but FEV1 decreases proportionately less or remains preserved, leading to a Normal or High FEV1/FVC ratio.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (3 times repeated) - Cor pulmonale means:
options: Right ventricular failure due to mitral stenosis
Right ventricular failure due to left ventricular failure
Right ventricular failure due to lung disease
Right ventricular failure due to ventricular septal defect
questions.explanation: Cor Pulmonale is defined as Right Ventricular hypertrophy or failure resulting specifically from diseases affecting the lung structure or function (e.g., COPD, Pulmonary HTN), excluding cardiac causes like Left HF.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following does not precipitate manifestations of heart failure?
questions.explanation: Diabetes is a chronic risk factor, not an acute precipitating factor like infections, thyrotoxicosis/myxedema, or fluid overload which can suddenly decompensate stable HF.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - What is the indication of phosphodiesterase E4 inhibitor in COPD?
options: Chronic bronchitis with history of exacerbation
questions.explanation: Roflumilast (PDE4 inhibitor) is indicated specifically for severe COPD associated with chronic bronchitis and a history of frequent exacerbations to reduce inflammation.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Left-sided heart failure is manifested by:
questions.explanation: Basal lung crackles (Crepitations) are due to pulmonary venous congestion/edema, a direct sign of Left Heart Failure. JVP, edema, ascites, and hepatomegaly are signs of Right HF.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: The best vasodilator used in treatment of chronic heart failure is:
questions.explanation: ACE inhibitors are the gold standard vasodilators for chronic heart failure as they reduce both preload and afterload and improve survival (mortality benefit).
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: The gold standard in establishing a diagnosis of GERD is:
questions.explanation: 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring is the Gold Standard for diagnosing GERD, specifically when endoscopy is normal or symptoms are atypical.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Which of the following is not advocated in the treatment of acute pulmonary edema?
questions.explanation: Trendelenburg position (head down) increases venous return to the heart, worsening pulmonary congestion. Patients should be sat up (Semi-Fowler's) to reduce preload.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following regarding chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is not true?
options: Most common cause of microcytic hypochromic anemia
questions.explanation: CML does not cause microcytic hypochromic anemia (which is typical of Iron deficiency or Thalassemia). CML typically presents with leukocytosis and normocytic anemia.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Complications of GERD include which of the following?
questions.explanation: Barrett's esophagus (intestinal metaplasia) is a specific complication of chronic GERD and is a precursor to esophageal adenocarcinoma.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Which is false regarding Reye’s syndrome?
options: Survivors pass on to chronic liver disease
May be associated with fulminant hepatic failure
questions.explanation: Survivors of Reye's syndrome typically recover liver function completely without progression to chronic liver disease. It is an acute illness.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Diabetic Peripheral Neuropathy does not include:
questions.explanation: Quadriceps wasting is characteristic of Diabetic Amyotrophy (a proximal motor neuropathy/radiculoplexopathy), which is distinct from the typical distal symmetric polyneuropathy or autonomic neuropathy listed in the other options.
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: The patient's’serum contains only anti-Hepatitis B surface antibody. it is:
options: Suffering from chronic Hepatitis E infection
Carrier with low level of Hepatitis B surface antigen
questions.explanation: The presence of isolated Anti-HBs (Surface Antibody) without Core Antibody (Anti-HBc) indicates immunity due to Vaccination. Natural immunity would include Anti-HBc.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: A patient presenting with an arterial blood pressure of 135/85 needs:
questions.explanation: BP 135/85 falls into the 'Pre-hypertension' or 'High Normal' category (depending on guidelines). The initial management is lifestyle modification (diet, exercise) unless compelling comorbidities exist.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Hemolytic anemia is characterized by the following, except:
questions.explanation: The fundamental definition of hemolytic anemia is the shortened lifespan of red blood cells (<120 days). It cannot be normal.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: Mantoux test is used to diagnose:
questions.explanation: The Mantoux (Tuberculin Skin Test) assesses cell-mediated immunity to Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is used to screen for latent or active TB.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Treatment of autoimmune hepatitis includes:
questions.explanation: Corticosteroids (with or without Azathioprine) are the mainstay of treatment for Autoimmune Hepatitis to suppress the immune response.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Slow rising pulse is a feature of:
questions.explanation: A slow-rising (Pulsus Parvus et Tardus) pulse is characteristic of Aortic Stenosis due to the obstruction of LV outflow delaying the peak systolic pressure.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Asymmetric expansion of the chest is due to:
options: Endobronchial obstruction of a large airway
questions.explanation: Obstruction of a large airway (e.g., foreign body, tumor) causes collapse/atelectasis of that lung side, leading to reduced expansion on that side (Asymmetry). COPD and Asthma typically cause symmetrical findings.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: To establish the diagnosis of hypertension we should:
questions.explanation: Diagnosis of hypertension generally requires repeated blood pressure measurements on separate occasions (or ABPM) to confirm persistent elevation.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding cyanosis:
options: One of manifestations of respiratory failure.
Lips are reliable site for recognition of central cyanosis.
Stagnant circulation is one of possible mechanisms.
Central cyanosis indicates more than 5 grams of reduced HB in aorta.
questions.explanation: Lips can be affected by peripheral factors (cold). The tongue and oral mucous membranes are the most reliable sites for recognizing central cyanosis.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Long-term oxygen therapy is indicated in which of the following conditions in COPD patient:
options: FEV1 less than 50% of predicted normal value.
questions.explanation: LTOT is indicated for chronic resting hypoxemia (PaO2 < 55 mmHg) or nocturnal hypoxemia with complications (Cor Pulmonale). It improves survival.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Which of the following drugs may worsen manifestations of heart failure:
questions.explanation: Verapamil (a non-dihydropyridine Calcium Channel Blocker) is a negative inotrope and can worsen heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Patient with essential hypertension presented for the first time with BP 150/90 without evidence of target organ damage. What is the most appropriate management?
options: Non-pharmacological measures and ambulatory BP follow-up.
questions.explanation: For Stage 1 HTN (140-159/90-99) without organ damage or high CV risk, lifestyle measures and confirmation via Ambulatory BP Monitoring (ABPM) is the standard initial step.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is not appropriate in which of the following conditions:
questions.explanation: Rectal bleeding and anemia are 'Alarm Symptoms' (Red Flags) that suggest organic pathology (IBD, Cancer) and rule out a diagnosis of simple IBS.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Myocarditis is not characterized by:
questions.explanation: Myocarditis typically causes myocardial depression and Hypotension, not hypertension. It presents with tachycardia, enzymes, and failure.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Liver cirrhosis is not usually caused by:
questions.explanation: Paracetamol overdose causes Acute Liver Failure (necrosis), not chronic cirrhosis. Cirrhosis requires chronic inflammation/fibrosis over time.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding diabetic polyneuropathy:
options: Vitamin B complex and folic acid are usually given.
Contributes to pathogenesis of diabetic foot.
questions.explanation: Diabetic polyneuropathy is primarily a Sensory neuropathy (glove and stocking distribution). Pure motor involvement is rare and usually suggests another etiology.
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Atrial fibrillation is distinguished from multiple extra-systoles by:
questions.explanation: A significant pulse deficit (>10 bpm difference between apical and radial pulse) is characteristic of Atrial Fibrillation due to variable diastolic filling and non-perfusing beats.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following may distinguish pulmonary versus cardiac etiology of dyspnea:
options: Significantly elevated serum level of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP).
questions.explanation: BNP is released by stretched ventricular myocytes. Elevated BNP strongly suggests a Cardiac cause (Heart Failure) of dyspnea, whereas normal BNP suggests a Pulmonary cause.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Most common cause of COPD exacerbation is:
questions.explanation: Respiratory tract infections (viral or bacterial) are the most common trigger for acute exacerbations of COPD.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Pyramidal tract lesion is not associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation: Cogwheel rigidity is a sign of Extrapyramidal lesions (e.g., Parkinsonism). Pyramidal lesions cause Spasticity (Clasp-knife type).
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: Definitive diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma is made by:
questions.explanation: Lymph node biopsy is required to demonstrate the pathognomonic Reed-Sternberg cells and architecture for the diagnosis of Hodgkin Lymphoma.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Dullness of Kronig’s isthmus is usually not seen in:
questions.explanation: Kronig's isthmus (apical lung resonance) becomes dull in apical pathologies like TB, Pancoast tumor, or fibrosis. Bronchiectasis typically affects the lower lobes and does not cause apical dullness.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (3 times repeated) - The most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia is:
questions.explanation: Streptococcus pneumoniae (Pneumococcus) is globally the most common bacterial pathogen causing Community-Acquired Pneumonia (CAP).
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Stroke is defined by acute onset of:
options: Focal neurological deficit caused by thrombotic or hemorrhagic lesion
Focal neurological deficit caused by demyelinating lesion
Focal neurological deficit caused by degenerative lesion
Focal neurological deficit caused by inflammatory lesion
Focal neurological deficit caused by neoplastic lesion
questions.explanation: Stroke is specifically a vascular event. It is defined as a focal neurological deficit of vascular origin (ischemic or hemorrhagic) lasting >24 hours.
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: Which of the following criteria may be a warning sign regarding chest pain?
options: Central, compressing, prolonged and associated with dyspnea and diaphoresis
questions.explanation: Central, compressing pain with autonomic symptoms (diaphoresis) and dyspnea is classic for Acute Coronary Syndrome (MI) and is a major warning sign.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Causes of transient hemiplegia include:
questions.explanation: Todd's paralysis is a transient neurological deficit (hemiplegia) that occurs after a seizure and resolves spontaneously. Embolic/Thrombotic cause stroke (lasting).
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Malabsorption syndrome may be associated with which of the following?
questions.explanation: Celiac disease is a classic cause of malabsorption due to autoimmune damage to the small intestinal villi upon exposure to gluten.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: A man presenting with dyspnea, on examination: pulsus alternans was felt, S3 gallop, and bilateral basal lung crackles were audible. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation: S3 gallop, Pulsus alternans, and basal crackles are the classic triad of signs for decompensated Left Ventricular Failure.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: One of the following antihypertensive drugs commonly causes dry irritant cough:
questions.explanation: ACE inhibitors cause a dry cough in up to 20% of patients due to the accumulation of Bradykinin in the lungs.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Syncope best described by which of the following statements:
options: Prolonged state of disturbed conscious level
Sudden and transient loss of consciousness caused by cardiac, neurogenic and postural mechanisms
questions.explanation: Syncope is defined as a transient, self-terminating loss of consciousness and postural tone due to global cerebral hypoperfusion.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following may cause sudden cardiac death in young age:
questions.explanation: HOCM is the most common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes due to fatal arrhythmias.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Most common cause of myocarditis:
questions.explanation: Viral infections (e.g., Coxsackie B, Adenovirus) are the most common etiology of myocarditis.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Conditions associated with microcytosis (microcytic anemia) do not include:
questions.explanation: Acute hemolysis typically causes normocytic anemia (or macrocytic if reticulocytosis is high). Microcytosis is seen in Iron deficiency, Thalassemia, Sideroblastic anemia, and chronic disease.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: (3 times repeated) - Pancytopenia is not associated with:
questions.explanation: G6PD deficiency causes episodic hemolysis (low RBCs only), not pancytopenia. Pancytopenia implies bone marrow failure or splenic sequestration of all lines.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: Irritable bowel syndrome is characterized by:
questions.explanation: IBS is a chronic functional disorder characterized by recurrent (chronic) abdominal pain associated with defecation or change in bowel habits.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Which of the following does not differentiate between hemoptysis and hematemesis:
questions.explanation: Both hemoptysis (respiratory bleeding) and hematemesis (GI bleeding) can be severe enough to cause anemia, so this does not distinguish between them. pH (acid vs alkaline), color (bright vs dark), and contents (food vs froth) do.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Which of the following is not a common cause for subtotal villous atrophy:
questions.explanation: C. difficile causes pseudomembranous colitis, not villous atrophy. Villous atrophy is seen in Celiac, Tropical Sprue, Giardiasis, and other malabsorptive states.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: The tone of the muscles affected by gradually progressive upper motor neuron lesion would be:
questions.explanation: UMN lesions cause Spasticity (velocity-dependent increase in tone). Rigidity is extrapyramidal; flaccidity is LMN.
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - The presence of fever, arthralgia, erythema nodosum, hilar lymphadenopathy defines:
questions.explanation: Lofgren's syndrome is a specific acute clinical presentation of Sarcoidosis characterized by the triad of Erythema Nodosum, Bilateral Hilar Lymphadenopathy, and Arthralgia/Fever.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Female patient presented by thrombocytopenia, anemia, leukocytosis and abnormal blast cells in peripheral blood film. The most appropriate second step is:
questions.explanation: The presence of blasts in the peripheral blood with cytopenias suggests Acute Leukemia. Bone marrow aspiration/biopsy is the mandatory next step to confirm diagnosis and type.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: The first line therapy of systemic hypertension is:
questions.explanation: ACE inhibitors (or ARBs, CCBs, Thiazides) are first-line agents. Beta-blockers and Alpha-blockers are no longer first-line for uncomplicated hypertension.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - Surest clinical sign in emphysema:
options: Encroachment on both hepatic and cardiac dullness
questions.explanation: Hyperinflation in emphysema causes the lungs to expand, encroaching on and diminishing the area of cardiac and hepatic dullness on percussion.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Which of the following is the most useful in the management of acute heart failure:
questions.explanation: Loop Diuretics (e.g., Furosemide) are the cornerstone of management in Acute Heart Failure to relieve pulmonary congestion/edema.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Ascites precox may occur in:
questions.explanation: Ascites Precox (ascites appearing before leg edema) is a classic sign of Constrictive Pericarditis due to high systemic venous pressure affecting the liver surface.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: (3 times repeated) - 65 years old male presented to ER by severe central chest pain referred to the back, on examination there was unequal pulse volume. What is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Severe tearing chest pain radiating to the back combined with pulse deficits (unequal pulses) is the classic presentation of Aortic Dissection.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: One of the most reliable markers for renal injury and cardiovascular disease is:
questions.explanation: Microalbuminuria (Albumin/Creatinine ratio) is an early and sensitive marker for endothelial dysfunction, renal injury (nephropathy), and cardiovascular risk.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following conditions will exclude functional gastrointestinal disorders:
options: Duration of symptoms is only 3 months
questions.explanation: Positive Fecal Calprotectin indicates intestinal inflammation (e.g., IBD), which excludes functional disorders like IBS.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Paroxysmal hypertension is classically found in:
questions.explanation: Pheochromocytoma releases bursts of catecholamines, leading to episodic (paroxysmal) hypertension accompanied by headache, palpitations, and sweating.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: The characteristic pathological finding of sarcoidosis is:
questions.explanation: Non-caseating granulomas are the hallmark histological finding in Sarcoidosis. Caseating granulomas are typical of TB.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Which of the following can cause high cardiac output failure:
questions.explanation: Thyrotoxicosis increases metabolic demand and causes vasodilation, leading to High Output Heart Failure. The others cause low output failure.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of beta thalassemia major:
questions.explanation: Thalassemia Major is associated with Iron Overload (due to hemolysis and transfusions), not Iron Deficiency. All other options are features of the disease.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: Typical anginal pain is not characterized by:
questions.explanation: Tearing pain is characteristic of Aortic Dissection. Angina is typically described as heavy, pressure, or squeezing.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following does not cause bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy:
questions.explanation: Pneumonia typically causes parenchymal consolidation, not bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy. BHL is seen in Sarcoidosis, Lymphoma, and TB.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Spirometry in COPD usually reveals:
questions.explanation: COPD is an Obstructive Lung Disease, defined by a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (<0.70).
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Celiac disease is not characterized by:
questions.explanation: Celiac disease typically causes chronic diarrhea/steatorrhea due to malabsorption, not constipation.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of acute dyspnea:
questions.explanation: Bronchogenic carcinoma typically presents with chronic, progressive dyspnea. PE, Pneumothorax, Anaphylaxis, and Tamponade are causes of sudden/acute dyspnea.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: The most reliable symptom of acute pulmonary embolism is:
questions.explanation: Shortness of breath (dyspnea) is the most common and reliable symptom of PE, present in over 80% of cases.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Most common cause of upper gastrointestinal bleeding is:
questions.explanation: Peptic Ulcer Disease is the leading cause of upper GI bleeding, accounting for 30-40% of cases.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Iron deficiency anemia may be caused by:
questions.explanation: Chronic blood loss (e.g., GI bleeding, menorrhagia) depletes iron stores over time, leading to iron deficiency. Acute bleeding causes normocytic anemia.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: Hepatic failure may produce:
questions.explanation: Asterixis (Flapping Tremor) is a hallmark sign of hepatic encephalopathy caused by metabolic dysfunction in liver failure.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Which of the following causes dyspnea with normal cardiorespiratory function:
questions.explanation: Anemia causes dyspnea due to reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, while the heart and lungs themselves may be structurally and functionally normal (initially).
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: (2 times repeated) - The color of urine is normal in jaundice caused by:
questions.explanation: Gilbert syndrome causes unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Unconjugated bilirubin is not water-soluble and does not appear in urine (acholuric jaundice). The other options cause conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (dark urine).
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: 17-year-old male with malaise, anorexia, fever, nausea, jaundice, dark urine, pale stool. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.explanation: The prodrome of viral symptoms (fever, malaise) followed by jaundice, dark urine, and pale stool in a young person is the classic presentation of Acute Viral Hepatitis A.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Example of transudative ascites is:
questions.explanation: Liver cirrhosis causes portal hypertension, leading to transudative ascites (Low SAAG > 1.1 g/dL implies portal HTN, but often simple distinction calls cirrhosis transudate vs TB/Cancer exudate). Note: Cirrhosis is high gradient (Transudate-like mechanics), TB/Malig are low gradient (Exudate).
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Which is not a cause of sinus bradycardia:
questions.explanation: Complete Heart Block is a dissociation between atria and ventricles; it is not 'Sinus' bradycardia. The sinus node may be firing normally, but ventricles are slow. The others suppress the sinus node.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following is a centrally acting antihypertensive drug:
questions.explanation: Methyldopa is a central alpha-2 agonist. Prazosin is an alpha-1 blocker (peripheral), Atenolol is a beta-blocker.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which is false regarding edema in congestive heart failure:
options: Due to salt and water retention
questions.explanation: Cardiac edema typically accumulates during the day due to gravity and is worse in the evening, not the morning. Renal edema (e.g., periorbital) is often noticed in the morning.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Worldwide commonest cause of hemoptysis is:
questions.explanation: Pulmonary Tuberculosis remains the most common cause of hemoptysis worldwide, especially in endemic regions.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Woody dullness on chest percussion is classically found in:
questions.explanation: Woody dullness is a specific percussion note associated with Thickened Pleura. Effusion is 'Stony dull'.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Most common cause of acute corpulmonale is:
questions.explanation: Acute Cor Pulmonale (acute RV strain) is most commonly caused by a massive Pulmonary Thromboembolism.
questions.subject: Cardiology

questions.question: Which of the following is not a complication of pneumonia:
questions.explanation: Pancreatitis is not a recognized complication of pneumonia. Pneumonia can spread locally (effusion, empyema) or cause sepsis/abscess.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Most commonly affected organ in sarcoidosis:
questions.explanation: The lungs and intrathoracic lymph nodes are involved in over 90% of Sarcoidosis cases.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of upper motor neuron lesion:
questions.explanation: Fasciculations (visible muscle twitches) are a sign of Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) degeneration/irritation, not UMN.
questions.subject: Neurology

questions.question: Macrocytic anemia is found in:
questions.explanation: Pernicious anemia (B12 deficiency) causes Megaloblastic (Macrocytic) anemia. Iron deficiency and Thalassemia cause Microcytic anemia.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: Pica is a symptom of:
questions.explanation: Pica (craving non-food items like ice/dirt) is a specific and classic symptom of Iron Deficiency Anemia.
questions.subject: Hematology

questions.question: GERD complications do not include:
questions.explanation: GERD affects the upper GI tract. It causes Esophagitis, Strictures, Barrett's, and Esophageal adenocarcinoma, but is not a risk factor for Colon Cancer.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Hemoptysis is not common in:
questions.explanation: While severe coughing in asthma can rarely cause minor bleeding, hemoptysis is not a common or typical feature of asthma and suggests another diagnosis.
questions.subject: Respiratory

questions.question: Main treatment of celiac disease:
questions.explanation: Lifelong adherence to a Gluten-Free Diet is the only effective treatment for Celiac Disease.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: Which is not a complication of hepatic cirrhosis?
questions.explanation: Cirrhosis causes Thrombocytopenia (low platelets) due to hypersplenism and reduced thrombopoietin. Thrombocytosis is not a complication.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver

questions.question: First-line pharmacological agent in upper gastrointestinal bleeding from oesophageal varices:
questions.explanation: Vasoactive drugs like Octreotide (somatostatin analogue) or Terlipressin are the first-line pharmacological treatment to lower portal pressure and stop variceal bleeding.
questions.subject: GIT & Liver
